title: Do you think the technology of the past was much superior to what we have today? Perhaps we lost it, and even records were lost. - Quora

response.answer_text: No. Not only would the technology and the records needed to have been lost but all physical evidence along with it, because all the mysterious stuff left behind is well within our capability to recreate either faster or to a higher standard or both. We might not be quite sure how Mayans dressed stone as neatly as they did but we could certainly do it even better now. We might not be sure how the megaliths of Stonehenge were moved around but we can shift far heavier loads around. We might not understand exactly how the Nazca Lines were created but we could easily do larger and more complex versions now if we wanted. We might not know for certain how the pyramids were built but you can be absolutely sure that if we can build a habitable tower over half a mile high we could certainly recreate the largest pyramid the ancient Egyptians ever managed, and probably make one a lot bigger if we chose. Any obstacles are usually economic rather than technological: why would anyone want to built a bloody great pyramid now? But tell any of those ancient people that we could fly around the world in a day at the height of the highest mountains or that there’d be a metal building in space that was travelling faster than a bullet from a rifle… and then you showed them a rifle and how fast a bullet goes… yeah, if you did that they’d be absolutely incredulous and marvel at how people ever learned to do that. Unless they thought it was all witchcraft and murdered you to death.

There are folkloric tales of ancient gods, heroes, and nations that performed mighty deeds. While they carry much cultural significance, in the end they are ancient versions of the comic book heroes of today. Many people like to speculate that those ancient tales are literally true. They aren't. When people point at megalithic (large stone) structures as examples of inexplicable technology, they are reasoning that if we do not understand how they were built, some kind of magically advanced technology must have been involved. Actually, we don't know how they were built because our ancestors figured out a long, long time ago that there were easier ways to build than moving really big stones around. It is also the case though, that while ancient people may have been ignorant by our standards, they were not stupid. In the field of experimental archeology a number of trials have been performed to show that people using clever but simple techniques can move large stones far more easily than we have thought. Yes, we did lose that technology, but It was not supreme to ours.

I really-really doubt it. The technology of olde would still have had to conform to the laws of physics and the rules of engineering that we have today. And our understanding of these laws and rules today is infinitely better than what we had 100 or 1000 years ago. So, I have significant doubt that the technology of olde in any ways could have in principle been better than what we have now. Now, some things done in the past could be of superior quality even to what is commonly available today. That’s because the maker of it were not subject to the same constraints of time and money that a manufacturer of today would be. Plus, we also have to separate the myth of some ancient tech from the reality of it. I.e. many things like the efficacy of “magical” swords of the past have been greatly exaggerated. The issue here being that it were totally possible to have a proper steel sword back in the bronze age. Even if you were producing small quantities of iron as an exotic thing, not enough for everyone - steel in very small quantity would be a byproduct. And out of that steel one could make something. And you can imagine how superior that one of a kind artefact would be to a bronze sword that a commoner might have. Not to mention that people would just lie like in the case of the “Greek fire” to impress their enemies.
